title: Polygamy Triads: I've read about real life FMF triads, but can only find MFM triads in fiction. Are they really that uncommon? - Quora

response.answer_text: The big question for me, is do you mean triad in the sense that they are a “full” triad, where each of the three is in a romantic and/or sexual relationship with each other, or a “v” type triad, where two of the people are just friends with each other. The full triad doesn’t happen as often, though it definitely does exist. To briefly digress: If we use the old Kinsey scale (which isn’t perfect, but will do for this example), a woman or a man who is a “0” would call themselves heterosexual. A woman or man that are a “6” would call themselves homosexual. Then the differences happen. Through a mix of societal inclinations, pornography standards, and more, women who are a 1–5 on the scale will likely call themselves bisexual or at least bicurious. Men who are a 1 or a 5 are extremely likely to still say they are straight or gay, because of the social stigmas around bi men. Some of those stigmas around bi men lead to women not dating a bi man because “he’s actually gay” and men not dating that same bi man because “he’ll probably cheat.” Meanwhile, straight guys in general are happy dating a bi woman, because “that’s hot,” and while some lesbians won’t date bi women (gold star lesbian and all that), it’s nowhere near the flak bi men get. So, because of all of that, full FMF triads tend to be more visible and more common than full MFM triads. However, in my anecdotal experience, MFM “v” shaped polycules seem to be one of the most common arrangements, if not THE most common arrangement (tying with “open web of partners” which is less a specific structure because once you get past 4–5 people, each configuration is too specific to name). Now, taking into account the concerns about bi men above - is it likely that some of these “v” shapes are actually full triads? Almost certainly. While both of my guys are straight, they care about each other a lot. I’m definitely not the only thing tying them together. If they weren’t straight, we’d probably form a full triad, but they are, and unless that changes, we’ll be staying a “v.”
